docs.title: Devo CLI
docs.text: AI-powered command-line tool for development workflows with AWS Bedrock integration.

docs.title: What is Devo CLI?
docs.text: Devo CLI is a Python-based command-line tool that enhances developer productivity through AI-powered features and AWS integration. It helps teams maintain consistent commit messages, perform automated code reviews, and streamline development workflows.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• AI-Powered Commit Messages: Generate conventional commit messages from staged changes using AWS Bedrock (Claude 3.7 Sonnet)
  • Automated Code Review: AI-driven code analysis with security checks and best practices validation
  • Self-Updating: Keep your CLI up-to-date with a single command
  • AWS Integration: Seamless CodeArtifact authentication and Bedrock AI model access
  • Shell Completion: Tab completion support for bash, zsh, and fish
  • Standalone Binaries: No Python installation required for end users

docs.title: Binary Distribution Formats
docs.text: This document explains the different binary formats used for each platform and why.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Devo CLI uses PyInstaller to create standalone binaries. Different platforms use different packaging modes optimized for their use case.

docs.title: Linux: Single Binary (onefile)
docs.text:
Format: Single executable file File: devo-linux-amd64 Size: ~50-80 MB

Why onefile? - Easy distribution (single file to download) - Simple installation (just copy to PATH) - Acceptable startup time on Linux systems - Standard for Linux CLI tools

Startup time: ~0.5-1s (extraction overhead acceptable)

docs.title: macOS: Directory Bundle (onedir)
docs.text:
Format: Directory with executable and dependencies Distribution: .tar.gz archive File: devo-darwin-arm64.tar.gz or devo-darwin-amd64.tar.gz Extracted size: ~60-90 MB

Why onedir? - Fast startup: ~0.1-0.3s (no extraction needed) - Avoids 2-5s startup delay from onefile mode - Better user experience for frequent CLI usage - Standard for macOS applications

Startup time: ~0.1-0.3s (instant, no extraction)

docs.title: Windows: Directory Bundle (onedir)
docs.text:
Format: Directory with executable and dependencies Distribution: .zip archive File: devo-windows-amd64.zip Extracted size: ~60-90 MB

Why onedir? - Fast startup: ~0.1-0.3s (no extraction needed) - Avoids extraction overhead - Better antivirus compatibility - Standard for Windows applications

Startup time: ~0.1-0.3s (instant, no extraction)

docs.title: Performance Comparison
docs.text: Platform Mode Startup Time Distribution Size Linux onefile ~0.5-1s Single file ~50-80 MB macOS onedir ~0.1-0.3s .tar.gz ~60-90 MB Windows onedir ~0.1-0.3s .zip ~60-90 MB

docs.title: onefile Mode (Linux)
docs.text:
• Extracts to temporary directory on each run
  • Adds 2-5s startup overhead on macOS/Windows
  • Acceptable on Linux due to faster I/O
  • Simpler distribution (single file)

docs.title: onedir Mode (macOS/Windows)
docs.text:
• No extraction needed (files already on disk)
  • Near-instant startup
  • Better for frequent CLI usage
  • Requires directory structure

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
# Download single binary
curl -L https://github.com/edu526/devo-cli/releases/latest/download/devo-linux-amd64 -o devo
chmod +x devo
sudo mv devo /usr/local/bin/

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
# Download and extract tarball
curl -L https://github.com/edu526/devo-cli/releases/latest/download/devo-darwin-arm64.tar.gz -o devo.tar.gz
tar -xzf devo.tar.gz
sudo mv devo-darwin-arm64 /usr/local/bin/devo-app
sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/devo-app/devo /usr/local/bin/devo

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
# Download and extract zip
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://github.com/edu526/devo-cli/releases/latest/download/devo-windows-amd64.zip" -OutFile "devo.zip"
Expand-Archive devo.zip -DestinationPath "C:\Program Files\devo"
# Add to PATH

docs.title: Upgrade Behavior
docs.text:
The devo upgrade command handles each format automatically:

  • Linux: Downloads single binary, replaces in place
  • macOS: Downloads tarball, extracts, replaces directory
  • Windows: Downloads zip, extracts, uses PowerShell script for replacement

docs.title: PyInstaller Configuration
docs.text:
See devo.spec for the full configuration:

if sys.platform == 'linux':
    # onefile mode
    exe = EXE(pyz, a.scripts, a.binaries, a.zipfiles, a.datas, ...)
else:
    # onedir mode (macOS/Windows)
    exe = EXE(pyz, a.scripts, [], exclude_binaries=True, ...)
    coll = COLLECT(exe, a.binaries, a.zipfiles, a.datas, ...)

docs.title: Why Not onefile Everywhere?
docs.text:
We tested onefile mode on all platforms and found:

  • Linux: 0.5-1s startup (acceptable)
  • macOS: 2-5s startup (too slow for CLI tool)
  • Windows: 2-5s startup (too slow for CLI tool)

The onedir mode eliminates this overhead on macOS/Windows while keeping Linux simple with a single file.

docs.text:
Purpose: Run tests and build verification on pull requests

# → Opens PR → Triggers test workflow

docs.title: 2. Release Workflow (.github/workflows/release.yml)
docs.text:
Purpose: Automated versioning and release creation

Triggers: - Push to main branch - Manual trigger via GitHub UI

Jobs:

  1. test - Run full test suite
  2. check-version - Analyze commits to determine if release is needed
  3. build-binaries - Build standalone binaries for all platforms
  4. create-release - Create GitHub Release with semantic versioning
  5. upload-assets - Upload binaries and checksums to release
  6. notify-telegram - Send notification (optional)

Example: 

git commit -m "feat: add new feature"
git push origin main
# → Triggers release workflow
# → Creates release v1.1.0 with binaries

  2. Determines if new release is needed
  3. Calculates next version number
  4. Builds all binaries
  5. Creates git tag and GitHub release
  6. Uploads binaries and checksums
  7. Updates CHANGELOG.md

Release includes: - All platform binaries - SHA256SUMS file - Auto-generated release notes from commits

docs.title: Semantic Release
docs.text: This project uses python-semantic-release for automated versioning and releases.

docs.title: Conventional Commits
docs.text:
Semantic Release analyzes commit messages following the Conventional Commits specification:

<type>(<scope>): <subject>

docs.title: Version Bumping
docs.text:
Based on commit types:

Commit Type Version Bump Example feat: Minor (0.X.0) feat: add new command fix: Patch (0.0.X) fix: resolve bug in parser perf: Patch (0.0.X) perf: improve startup time BREAKING CHANGE: Major (X.0.0) feat!: redesign CLI interface

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text:
Developer commits with conventional format
    ↓
Push to main branch
    ↓
Release Workflow
    ├─ Analyze commits (python-semantic-release)
    ├─ Determine next version
    ├─ Build binaries
    ├─ Create git tag
    ├─ Update CHANGELOG.md
    ├─ Create GitHub release
    └─ Upload binaries

docs.title: Types
docs.text:
• feat: - New feature (minor version bump)
  • fix: - Bug fix (patch version bump)
  • perf: - Performance improvement (patch version bump)
  • docs: - Documentation changes (patch version bump)
  • style: - Code style changes (patch version bump)
  • refactor: - Code refactoring (patch version bump)
  • test: - Test changes (patch version bump)
  • build: - Build system changes (patch version bump)
  • ci: - CI configuration changes (patch version bump)
  • chore: - Other changes (no version bump)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Feature (minor bump): 

git commit -m "feat: add code generation command"
git commit -m "feat(cli): add --verbose flag to all commands"

Bug fix (patch bump): 

git commit -m "fix: resolve template rendering issue"
git commit -m "fix(parser): handle empty input correctly"

Breaking change (major bump): 

git commit -m "feat!: redesign CLI interface

BREAKING CHANGE: Command structure has changed"

Documentation (patch bump): 

git commit -m "docs: update installation instructions"

No release: 

git commit -m "chore: update dependencies"
git commit -m "ci: fix workflow syntax"

# 2. Determines version (e.g., 1.1.0)
# 3. Builds binaries
# 4. Creates tag v1.1.0
# 5. Updates CHANGELOG.md
# 6. Creates GitHub Release with binaries

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Always use conventional commits - Enables automatic versioning
  2. Write clear commit messages - Subject line: what changed
  3. Group related changes - One feature = one commit
  4. Use scopes for clarity - feat(cli):, fix(parser):
  5. Document breaking changes - Use ! and BREAKING CHANGE:

🚀 Code Reviewer - AI-Powered Code Analysis

Analyze code changes in your Git repository using AI agents. Perfect for PR reviews and continuous integration pipelines.

devo [OPTIONS]

devo completion [SHELL]

source ~/.bashrc

source ~/.zshrc

_DEVO_COMPLETE=fish_source devo | source

devo completion

docs.text:
1. Reload shell configuration:

eval "$(_DEVO_COMPLETE=bash_source devo)"

docs.title: Zsh
docs.text:

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The dynamodb command provides utilities for working with AWS DynamoDB tables, including listing tables, describing table schemas, and exporting table data to various formats.

docs.title: list
docs.text:
List all DynamoDB tables in the current AWS account and region.

devo dynamodb list [OPTIONS]

Options: - -r, --region TEXT - AWS region (default: us-east-1)

Examples: 

# List tables in default region
devo dynamodb list

# List tables in specific region
devo dynamodb list --region us-west-2

# With specific profile
devo --profile production dynamodb list

docs.title: describe
docs.text:
Show detailed information about a DynamoDB table including schema, indexes, and capacity settings.

devo dynamodb describe TABLE_NAME [OPTIONS]

Options: - -r, --region TEXT - AWS region (default: us-east-1)

Examples: 

devo dynamodb describe users-table
devo dynamodb describe orders-prod --region us-east-1

docs.title: export
docs.text:
Export DynamoDB table data to CSV, JSON, JSONL, or TSV format with advanced filtering and formatting options.

devo dynamodb export TABLE_NAME [OPTIONS]

Options:

docs.title: Output Options
docs.text: Option Description -o, --output PATH Output file path (default: <table_name>_<timestamp>.csv) -f, --format [csv\|json\|jsonl\|tsv] Output format (default: csv) --compress [gzip\|zip] Compress output file

docs.title: Data Selection
docs.text: Option Description -l, --limit INTEGER Maximum number of items to export -a, --attributes TEXT Comma-separated list of attributes to export --filter TEXT Filter expression for scan/query --filter-values TEXT Expression attribute values as JSON --filter-names TEXT Expression attribute names as JSON --key-condition TEXT Key condition expression for query --index TEXT Global or Local Secondary Index name to use

docs.title: Formatting Options
docs.text: Option Description -m, --mode [strings\|flatten\|normalize] Export mode (default: strings)• strings - Serialize nested objects as JSON strings• flatten - Flatten nested objects• normalize - Expand lists to multiple rows --null-value TEXT Value for NULL fields in CSV (default: empty string) --delimiter TEXT CSV delimiter (default: comma) --encoding TEXT File encoding (default: utf-8) --bool-format [lowercase\|uppercase\|numeric\|letter] Boolean format (default: lowercase)• lowercase - true/false• uppercase - True/False• numeric - 1/0• letter - t/f --metadata Include metadata header in CSV output --pretty Pretty print JSON output (ignored for JSONL)

docs.title: Performance Options
docs.text: Option Description --parallel-scan Use parallel scan for faster export (experimental) --segments INTEGER Number of parallel scan segments (default: 4)

docs.title: Other Options
docs.text:
Option Description --dry-run Show what would be exported without actually exporting -y, --yes Skip confirmation prompts --save-template TEXT Save current configuration as a template --use-template TEXT Use saved template configuration

Examples:

# Export entire table to CSV (default)
devo dynamodb export my-table

# Export to JSON with compression
devo dynamodb export my-table -f json --compress gzip

# Export to JSONL (JSON Lines - one object per line)
devo dynamodb export my-table -f jsonl

# Export specific attributes
devo dynamodb export my-table -a "id,name,email,status"

# Export with filter
devo dynamodb export my-table --filter "status = :status" --filter-values '{"status": "active"}'

# Query with key condition
devo dynamodb export my-table --key-condition "userId = :uid" --filter-values '{"uid": "user123"}'

# Export to TSV with custom delimiter
devo dynamodb export my-table -f tsv --delimiter "|"

# Parallel scan for large tables
devo dynamodb export large-table --parallel-scan --segments 8

docs.title: Building Binaries
docs.text: Guide for building standalone binaries of Devo CLI using PyInstaller.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Devo CLI can be distributed as standalone binaries that don't require Python installation. This is done using PyInstaller to bundle Python, dependencies, and the CLI into a single executable.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.12+
  • Virtual environment activated
  • Development dependencies installed
# Setup development environment
./setup-dev.sh

# Or manually
python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt
pip install -e .

docs.title: Build for Current Platform
docs.text:
make build-binary

This creates a binary in dist/ directory:

  • Linux: dist/devo (single file)
  • macOS: dist/devo/ (directory with executable)
  • Windows: dist/devo/ (directory with executable)

docs.title: Build with Platform-Specific Naming
docs.text:
make build-all

Creates binaries with platform identifiers:

  • Linux AMD64: dist/devo (single file)
  • macOS Intel: release/vX.Y.Z/devo-darwin-amd64.tar.gz (tarball)
  • macOS Apple Silicon: release/vX.Y.Z/devo-darwin-arm64.tar.gz (tarball)
  • Windows: release/vX.Y.Z/devo-windows-amd64.zip (zip archive)

docs.title: Using PyInstaller Directly
docs.text:
# Activate virtual environment
source venv/bin/activate

# Build binary
pyinstaller --onefile \
  --name devo \
  --add-data "cli_tool:cli_tool" \
  cli_tool/cli.py

docs.title: Custom Build Options
docs.text:
# With console window (default)
pyinstaller --onefile --name devo cli_tool/cli.py

# Without console window (Windows GUI)
pyinstaller --onefile --noconsole --name devo cli_tool/cli.py

# With icon
pyinstaller --onefile --icon=icon.ico --name devo cli_tool/cli.py

# With additional data files
pyinstaller --onefile \
  --add-data "config:config" \
  --add-data "templates:templates" \
  --name devo cli_tool/cli.py

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
# Build on Linux
make build-binary

# Output
dist/devo-linux-amd64

# Test
./dist/devo-linux-amd64 --version

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
# Build on macOS
make build-binary

# Output (depends on architecture)
dist/devo/devo  # Directory with executable and dependencies

# Test
./dist/devo/devo --version

Note: macOS uses onedir mode (directory with executable) for faster startup. Linux uses onefile mode (single binary) for easier distribution.

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
# Build on Windows
make build-binary

# Output
dist/devo-windows-amd64.exe

# Test
.\dist\devo-windows-amd64.exe --version

docs.title: Cross-Platform Building
docs.text:
PyInstaller cannot cross-compile. To build for multiple platforms:

  1. Use CI/CD: GitHub Actions builds for all platforms automatically
  2. Use VMs: Build on each platform separately
  3. Use Docker: Build Linux binaries in containers

docs.title: GitHub Actions (Recommended)
docs.text:
The project includes GitHub Actions workflow that builds for all platforms:

# .github/workflows/release.yml
- Build on ubuntu-latest → Linux binary
- Build on macos-latest → macOS Intel binary
- Build on macos-14 → macOS ARM binary
- Build on windows-latest → Windows binary

See CI/CD Overview for details.

docs.title: PyInstaller Spec File
docs.text:
For advanced configuration, create a .spec file:

# Generate spec file
pyi-makespec --onefile --name devo cli_tool/cli.py

# Edit devo.spec as needed

# Build from spec
pyinstaller devo.spec

Example devo.spec:

# -*- mode: python ; coding: utf-8 -*-

a = Analysis(
    ['cli_tool/cli.py'],
    pathex=[],
    binaries=[],
    datas=[('cli_tool', 'cli_tool')],
    hiddenimports=[],
    hookspath=[],
    hooksconfig={},
    runtime_hooks=[],
    excludes=[],
    noarchive=False,
)

pyz = PYZ(a.pure)

exe = EXE(
    pyz,
    a.scripts,
    a.binaries,
    a.datas,
    [],
    name='devo',
    debug=False,
    bootloader_ignore_signals=False,
    strip=False,
    upx=True,
    upx_exclude=[],
    runtime_tmpdir=None,
    console=True,
    disable_windowed_traceback=False,
    argv_emulation=False,
    target_arch=None,
    codesign_identity=None,
    entitlements_file=None,
)

docs.title: Configuration Guide
docs.text: This document describes all configuration options available in Devo CLI.

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
Devo CLI uses a JSON configuration file located at ~/.devo/config.json.

The configuration file is automatically created with default values on first run. You can manage it using the devo config command.

docs.title: View Configuration
docs.text:
# Show all configuration
devo config show

# Get specific value
devo config get aws.region
devo config get bedrock.model_id

docs.title: Modify Configuration
docs.text:
# Set a value
devo config set aws.region us-west-2
devo config set bedrock.model_id us.anthropic.claude-sonnet-4-20250514-v1:0
devo config set version_check.enabled false

# Edit in your default editor
devo config edit

# Show config file path
devo config path

# Validate configuration
devo config validate

# Reset to defaults
devo config reset

docs.title: Export/Import Configuration
docs.text:
# Export configuration to a file
devo config export my-config.json
devo config export ~/backup/devo-config-$(date +%Y%m%d).json

# Import configuration (replaces current)
devo config import my-config.json

# Import and merge with existing configuration
devo config import team-config.json --merge

Use cases:

  • Backup your configuration before making changes
  • Share configuration templates with your team
  • Sync configuration across multiple machines
  • Restore configuration after reset

docs.title: AWS Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "codeartifact": {
    "region": "us-east-1",
    "account_id": "123456789012",
    "sso_url": "https://my-org.awsapps.com/start",
    "required_role": "Developer",
    "domains": [
      {
        "domain": "my-domain",
        "repository": "npm",
        "namespace": "@myorg"
      }
    ]
  }
}
  • region: AWS region for all AWS operations
  • account_id: Required AWS account ID for authentication
  • sso_url: AWS SSO URL for obtaining credentials
  • required_role: Required IAM role name for operations

docs.title: Bedrock Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "bedrock": {
    "model_id": "us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0",
    "fallback_model_id": "us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0"
  }
}
  • model_id: AWS Bedrock model ID for AI features
  • fallback_model_id: Fallback model if primary fails

Available models:

  • us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0 (Claude 3.7 Sonnet - default)
  • us.anthropic.claude-sonnet-4-20250514-v1:0 (Claude Sonnet 4)

docs.title: GitHub Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "github": {
    "repo_owner": "edu526",
    "repo_name": "devo-cli"
  }
}
  • repo_owner: GitHub repository owner/organization
  • repo_name: GitHub repository name

docs.text:
{
  "codeartifact": {
    "region": "us-east-1",

docs.title: Version Check Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "version_check": {
    "enabled": true

  • enabled: Enable/disable automatic version checks

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Environment variables override configuration file values:

  • AWS_REGION - Override AWS region
  • AWS_ACCOUNT_ID - Override AWS account ID
  • AWS_SSO_URL - Override AWS SSO URL
  • AWS_REQUIRED_ROLE - Override required role
  • BEDROCK_MODEL_ID - Override Bedrock model ID
  • GITHUB_REPO_OWNER - Override GitHub repo owner
  • GITHUB_REPO_NAME - Override GitHub repo name
  • CODEARTIFACT_REGION - Override CodeArtifact region
  • DEVO_SKIP_VERSION_CHECK - Set to 1 to disable version checks

docs.title: Configuration Priority
docs.text:
Configuration is loaded in the following order (later sources override earlier ones):

  1. Default values (hardcoded in cli_tool/config.py)
  2. Configuration file (~/.devo/config.json)
  3. Environment variables
  4. Command-line arguments (where applicable)

docs.title: Custom AWS Configuration
docs.text:
devo config set aws.region eu-west-1
devo config set aws.account_id 123456789012
devo config set aws.sso_url https://mycompany.awsapps.com/start
devo config set aws.required_role Developer

docs.title: Disable Version Checks
docs.text:
devo config set version_check.enabled false

Or temporarily:

DEVO_SKIP_VERSION_CHECK=1 devo commit

docs.title: Custom GitHub Repository
docs.text:
devo config set github.repo_owner myorg
devo config set github.repo_name my-custom-cli

docs.title: Add CodeArtifact Registry
docs.text:
# List current registries
devo config registry list

# Add a new registry
devo config registry add --domain my-domain --repository my-repo --namespace @myorg

# Remove a registry by index
devo config registry remove 2

Or edit the configuration file directly:

devo config edit

Then add a new registry to the codeartifact.domains array:

{
  "domain": "my-domain",
  "repository": "my-repo",
  "namespace": "@myorg"
}

docs.title: Configuration Not Loading
docs.text:
1. Check file exists: devo config path
  2. Validate configuration: devo config validate
  3. Reset to defaults: devo config reset

docs.title: Configuration File Corrupted
docs.text:
# Reset to defaults
devo config reset

# Or manually delete and recreate
rm ~/.devo/config.json
devo config show  # Will create new default config

docs.title: AWS Credentials Issues
docs.text:
1. Verify account ID: devo config get aws.account_id
  2. Check SSO URL: devo config get aws.sso_url
  3. Verify with AWS CLI: aws sts get-caller-identity

docs.title: Bedrock Model Issues
docs.text:
1. Check model ID: devo config get bedrock.model_id
  2. Verify model is available in your region
  3. Try fallback model: devo config set bedrock.model_id us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0

docs.title: Security Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Protect config file - chmod 600 ~/.devo/config.json
  2. Don't share config - Contains account-specific information
  3. Use AWS SSO - Preferred over long-term credentials
  4. Rotate credentials - Update AWS credentials periodically
  5. Limit IAM permissions - Follow principle of least privilege

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Devo CLI can be installed as a standalone binary (recommended) or from source for development.

docs.title: Binary Installation (Recommended)
docs.text: No Python installation required. Download and run the installer:

docs.title: Linux/macOS
docs.text:
curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/edu526/devo-cli/main/install.sh | bash

The installer will:

  1. Detect your platform (Linux/macOS, architecture)
  2. Download the latest binary
  3. Install to /usr/local/bin (system-wide) or ~/.local/bin (user-only)
  4. Verify installation

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
Open PowerShell and run:

irm https://raw.githubusercontent.com/edu526/devo-cli/main/install.ps1 | iex

The installer will:

  1. Download the latest Windows binary
  2. Install to C:\Program Files\devo or user directory
  3. Add to PATH automatically
  4. Verify installation

Note: If you get an execution policy error, run: 

Set-ExecutionPolicy -Scope CurrentUser RemoteSigned

docs.title: Manual Binary Installation
docs.text: Download the binary for your platform from GitHub Releases:

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
# Download
curl -L https://github.com/edu526/devo-cli/releases/latest/download/devo-linux-amd64 -o devo

# Make executable
chmod +x devo

# Move to PATH
sudo mv devo /usr/local/bin/
# or for user-only:
mkdir -p ~/.local/bin && mv devo ~/.local/bin/

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
# Download and extract (Intel)
curl -L https://github.com/edu526/devo-cli/releases/latest/download/devo-darwin-amd64.tar.gz -o devo.tar.gz
tar -xzf devo.tar.gz

# Download and extract (Apple Silicon)
curl -L https://github.com/edu526/devo-cli/releases/latest/download/devo-darwin-arm64.tar.gz -o devo.tar.gz
tar -xzf devo.tar.gz

# Move to PATH (moves the entire directory)
sudo mv devo-darwin-* /usr/local/bin/devo-app
sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/devo-app/devo /usr/local/bin/devo

# Or for user-only installation:
mkdir -p ~/.local/bin
mv devo-darwin-* ~/.local/bin/devo-app
ln -s ~/.local/bin/devo-app/devo ~/.local/bin/devo

Note: macOS binaries are distributed as directories (not single files) for faster startup performance.

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
1. Download devo-windows-amd64.exe from releases
  2. Rename to devo.exe
  3. Move to a directory in your PATH (e.g., C:\Program Files\devo\)
  4. Add directory to PATH if needed

docs.title: AWS Setup Guide
docs.text: Devo CLI requires AWS credentials to access Bedrock AI models and CodeArtifact. This guide walks you through the setup process.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• AWS account with appropriate permissions
  • AWS CLI installed

docs.title: 1. Install AWS CLI
docs.text:
If not already installed:

# macOS
brew install awscli

# Linux
curl "https://awscli.amazonaws.com/awscli-exe-linux-x86_64.zip" -o "awscliv2.zip"
unzip awscliv2.zip
sudo ./aws/install

# Windows
# Download and run: https://awscli.amazonaws.com/AWSCLIV2.msi

docs.title: Option A: AWS Configure (Simple)
docs.text:
aws configure

Enter:

  • AWS Access Key ID
  • AWS Secret Access Key
  • Default region (e.g., us-east-1)
  • Default output format (e.g., json)

docs.title: Option B: AWS SSO (Recommended)
docs.text:
aws configure sso

Follow prompts to:

  1. Enter SSO start URL
  2. Enter SSO region
  3. Select account and role
  4. Set profile name

docs.title: 3. Verify Credentials
docs.text:
# Check identity
aws sts get-caller-identity

# Test Bedrock access
aws bedrock list-foundation-models --region us-east-1

docs.title: 4. Configure Devo CLI
docs.text:
# Set AWS region
devo config set aws.region us-east-1

# Set account ID (from get-caller-identity)
devo config set aws.account_id 123456789012

# For SSO users
devo config set aws.sso_url https://your-org.awsapps.com/start
devo config set aws.required_role Developer

docs.title: Required IAM Permissions
docs.text: Your AWS user/role needs these permissions:

docs.title: Bedrock Permissions
docs.text:
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": [
        "bedrock:InvokeModel",
        "bedrock:InvokeModelWithResponseStream"
      ],
      "Resource": [
        "arn:aws:bedrock:*::foundation-model/anthropic.claude-*"
      ]
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: CodeArtifact Permissions
docs.text:
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": [
        "codeartifact:GetAuthorizationToken",
        "codeartifact:GetRepositoryEndpoint",
        "codeartifact:ReadFromRepository"
      ],
      "Resource": "*"
    },
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": "sts:GetServiceBearerToken",
      "Resource": "*"
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: DynamoDB Export Guide
docs.text: Learn how to export DynamoDB table data to various formats for backup, analysis, and migration.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Export table to CSV
devo dynamodb export my-table

# Export to JSON with compression
devo dynamodb export my-table -f json --compress gzip

docs.title: Backup Tables
docs.text:
Create regular backups of your DynamoDB tables:

# Daily backup with timestamp
devo dynamodb export production-users \
  --output backup-$(date +%Y%m%d).json \
  -f json \
  --compress gzip

Add to cron for automated backups:

# Daily at 2 AM
0 2 * * * devo dynamodb export production-users -f json --compress gzip

docs.title: Data Analysis
docs.text:
Export data for analysis in Excel, Pandas, or other tools:

# Export to CSV for Excel
devo dynamodb export analytics-data -f csv

# Flatten nested objects for easier analysis
devo dynamodb export analytics-data -f csv --mode flatten

docs.title: Filtered Exports
docs.text:
Export only specific data:

# Export active users only
devo dynamodb export users \
  --filter "status = :s" \
  --filter-values '{"s": "active"}'

# Export specific user's data
devo dynamodb export orders \
  --key-condition "userId = :uid" \
  --filter-values '{"uid": "user123"}'

docs.title: Data Migration
docs.text:
Export from one environment and import to another:

# Export from production
devo --profile prod dynamodb export users -f jsonl

# Import to staging (using AWS CLI)
aws dynamodb batch-write-item --request-items file://users.jsonl --profile staging

docs.title: CSV (Default)
docs.text:
Best for Excel and spreadsheet analysis:

devo dynamodb export my-table -f csv

Output: 

id,name,email,status
1,John,john@example.com,active
2,Jane,jane@example.com,inactive

docs.title: JSON
docs.text:
Best for programmatic processing:

devo dynamodb export my-table -f json --pretty

Output: 

[
  {"id": 1, "name": "John", "email": "john@example.com"},
  {"id": 2, "name": "Jane", "email": "jane@example.com"}
]

docs.title: JSONL (JSON Lines)
docs.text:
Best for streaming and large datasets:

devo dynamodb export my-table -f jsonl

Output: 

{"id": 1, "name": "John", "email": "john@example.com"}
{"id": 2, "name": "Jane", "email": "jane@example.com"}

docs.title: TSV
docs.text:
Tab-separated format:

devo dynamodb export my-table -f tsv

docs.title: Strings Mode (Default)
docs.text:
Serializes nested objects as JSON strings:

devo dynamodb export my-table --mode strings

Output: 

id,name,metadata
1,John,"{\"age\": 30, \"city\": \"NYC\"}"

docs.title: Flatten Mode
docs.text:
Flattens nested objects into separate columns:

devo dynamodb export my-table --mode flatten

Output: 

id,name,metadata.age,metadata.city
1,John,30,NYC

docs.title: Normalize Mode
docs.text:
Expands lists into multiple rows:

devo dynamodb export my-table --mode normalize

Output: 

id,name,tag
1,John,developer
1,John,python

docs.title: Parallel Scan
docs.text:
For large tables, use parallel scanning:

# Use 8 parallel segments
devo dynamodb export large-table \
  --parallel-scan \
  --segments 8

Recommended segments by table size:

  • Small (<1GB): 2-4 segments
  • Medium (1-10GB): 4-8 segments
  • Large (>10GB): 8-16 segments

docs.title: Limit Results
docs.text:
Export only a subset of data:

# Export first 1000 items
devo dynamodb export my-table --limit 1000

docs.title: Save Export Configuration
docs.text:
Save frequently used export configurations:

devo dynamodb export my-table \
  -a "id,name,email,status" \
  --filter "status = :s" \
  --filter-values '{"s": "active"}' \
  --save-template active-users

docs.title: Use Saved Template
docs.text:
Reuse saved configurations:

devo dynamodb export my-table --use-template active-users

docs.title: List Templates
docs.text:
View all saved templates:

devo dynamodb list-templates

docs.title: Simple Filter
docs.text:
devo dynamodb export users \
  --filter "age > :age" \
  --filter-values '{"age": 18}'

docs.title: Multiple Conditions
docs.text:
devo dynamodb export users \
  --filter "status = :s AND age > :age" \
  --filter-values '{"s": "active", "age": 18}'

docs.title: Query with Key Condition
docs.text:
devo dynamodb export orders \
  --key-condition "userId = :uid AND orderDate > :date" \
  --filter-values '{"uid": "user123", "date": "2024-01-01"}'

docs.title: Using Index
docs.text:
devo dynamodb export users \
  --index email-index \
  --key-condition "email = :email" \
  --filter-values '{"email": "john@example.com"}'

docs.title: Select Specific Attributes
docs.text: devo dynamodb export users -a "id,name,email"

docs.title: Custom Delimiter
docs.text: devo dynamodb export users --delimiter "|"

docs.title: Boolean Format
docs.text:
# Numeric format (1/0)
devo dynamodb export users --bool-format numeric

# Uppercase (True/False)
devo dynamodb export users --bool-format uppercase

docs.title: Null Values
docs.text:
# Use "NULL" for null values
devo dynamodb export users --null-value "NULL"

docs.title: Include Metadata
docs.text:
# Add metadata header with export info
devo dynamodb export users --metadata

docs.title: Share Export Templates
docs.text:
# Export configuration
devo dynamodb export users \
  -a "id,name,email" \
  --save-template user-export

# Share template file with team
# Templates stored in: ~/.devo/dynamodb-templates/

docs.title: Automated Reports
docs.text:
Create scheduled exports:

#!/bin/bash
# daily-report.sh

DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d)
devo dynamodb export analytics \
  --use-template daily-report \
  --output reports/analytics-$DATE.csv

docs.title: Access Denied
docs.text:
Verify IAM permissions:

aws dynamodb list-tables --profile your-profile

Required permissions:

  • dynamodb:Scan
  • dynamodb:Query
  • dynamodb:DescribeTable

docs.title: Table Not Found
docs.text:
Check region and table name:

devo dynamodb list --region us-east-1

docs.title: Export Timeout
docs.text:
For large tables:

  1. Use parallel scan: --parallel-scan --segments 8
  2. Export in chunks: --limit 10000
  3. Use filters to reduce data: --filter

docs.title: Memory Issues
docs.text: For very large exports: 1. Use JSONL format instead of JSON 2. Enable compression: --compress gzip 3. Export specific attributes: -a "id,name"

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use compression for large exports: --compress gzip
  2. Save frequently used configurations: --save-template
  3. Use parallel scan for large tables: --parallel-scan
  4. Filter data when possible: Reduce export size with --filter
  5. Choose appropriate format: CSV for analysis, JSONL for processing
  6. Test with dry-run: --dry-run to preview before exporting
  7. Monitor costs: DynamoDB charges for read capacity

docs.title: Shell Completion Guide

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Shell completion allows you to:

  • Press TAB to autocomplete commands
  • See available options and subcommands
  • Speed up command entry
  • Discover commands interactively

docs.title: Zsh
docs.text:
Add to ~/.zshrc:

eval "$(_DEVO_COMPLETE=zsh_source devo)"

Then reload:

source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Bash

Add to ~/.bashrc:

eval "$(_DEVO_COMPLETE=bash_source devo)"

Then reload:

source ~/.bashrc

_DEVO_COMPLETE=fish_source devo | source

source ~/.config/fish/config.fish

# Type and press TAB
devo <TAB>

devo commit --<TAB>

docs.title: SSM Port Forwarding Guide
docs.text: Learn how to securely connect to private databases and services using AWS Systems Manager Session Manager with hostname support.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# 1. Add database
devo ssm add-db \
  --name mydb \
  --bastion i-0123456789abcdef0 \
  --host mydb.cluster-xyz.us-east-1.rds.amazonaws.com \
  --port 5432

# 2. Setup hostname forwarding
devo ssm hosts setup

# 3. Connect
devo ssm connect mydb

Your application can now use the real hostname without code changes!

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
Your App -> mydb.rds.amazonaws.com:5432
         |
         v
/etc/hosts resolves to 127.0.0.2
         |
         v
Port forwarder -> 127.0.0.1:local_port
         |
         v
SSM Session Manager (encrypted tunnel)
         |
         v
Bastion Instance
         |
         v
Database (RDS, ElastiCache, etc.)

docs.title: Install Session Manager Plugin
docs.text:
This is required for all platforms and is different from AWS CLI:

# Verify installation
session-manager-plugin

Installation guides:

  • Windows
  • macOS
  • Linux (Debian/Ubuntu)
  • Linux (RedHat/CentOS)

docs.title: Platform-Specific Requirements
docs.text:
Linux/macOS: 

# Install socat
brew install socat  # macOS
sudo apt-get install socat  # Ubuntu/Debian

Windows:

  • Run terminal as Administrator for hostname forwarding setup
  • netsh portproxy is built-in, no installation needed

docs.title: Single Database Setup
docs.text:
Connect to one database:

# 1. Add database configuration
devo ssm add-db \
  --name myapp-dev \
  --bastion i-0123456789abcdef0 \
  --host myapp-dev.cluster-xyz.us-east-1.rds.amazonaws.com \
  --port 5432 \
  --profile dev

# 2. Setup hostname forwarding
devo ssm hosts setup

# 3. Connect
devo ssm connect myapp-dev

Your application uses: 

# .env
DATABASE_HOST=myapp-dev.cluster-xyz.us-east-1.rds.amazonaws.com
DATABASE_PORT=5432

No code changes needed!

docs.title: Multiple Databases
docs.text:
Connect to multiple databases simultaneously:

# Add databases
devo ssm add-db --name dev-db --bastion i-xxx --host dev.rds.amazonaws.com --port 5432
devo ssm add-db --name prod-db --bastion i-yyy --host prod.rds.amazonaws.com --port 5432
devo ssm add-db --name redis --bastion i-xxx --host redis.cache.amazonaws.com --port 6379

# Setup all at once
devo ssm hosts setup

# Connect to all
devo ssm connect
# Select: "Connect to all databases"

Each database gets a unique loopback IP automatically, avoiding port conflicts.

docs.title: Team Configuration Sharing
docs.text:
Share database configurations with your team:

# Team lead exports configuration
devo ssm export team-ssm-config.json

# Share file via git, Slack, etc.

# Team members import
devo ssm import team-ssm-config.json

# Each person runs setup
devo ssm hosts setup

# Connect
devo ssm connect

docs.title: Multi-Environment Setup
docs.text:
Manage databases across different environments:

# Add databases for each environment
devo ssm add-db \
  --name myapp-dev \
  --bastion i-dev \
  --host dev.rds.amazonaws.com \
  --port 5432 \
  --profile dev

devo ssm add-db \
  --name myapp-staging \
  --bastion i-staging \
  --host staging.rds.amazonaws.com \
  --port 5432 \
  --profile staging

devo ssm add-db \
  --name myapp-prod \
  --bastion i-prod \
  --host prod.rds.amazonaws.com \
  --port 5432 \
  --profile prod

# Setup
devo ssm hosts setup

Your microservices use environment variables:

# .env.dev
DATABASE_HOST=dev.rds.amazonaws.com
DATABASE_PORT=5432

# .env.staging
DATABASE_HOST=staging.rds.amazonaws.com
DATABASE_PORT=5432

# .env.prod
DATABASE_HOST=prod.rds.amazonaws.com
DATABASE_PORT=5432

No code changes needed across environments!

devo ssm connect mydb --profile production

devo ssm connect mydb --no-hosts

DATABASE_HOST=localhost

docs.text: Press Ctrl+C to stop connections and clean up port forwarding rules.

devo ssm hosts setup

docs.text:
Install the plugin (separate from AWS CLI):

session-manager-plugin

# If not found, install from AWS documentation

docs.title: Permission Denied (Linux/macOS)
docs.text: The tool will prompt for sudo password when modifying /etc/hosts.

docs.title: Access Denied (Windows)
docs.text:
Run terminal as Administrator:

  1. Right-click Command Prompt/PowerShell
  2. Select "Run as administrator"
  3. Run devo ssm hosts setup

docs.title: Connection Refused
docs.text:
Check:

  1. Bastion instance is running
  2. Security groups allow SSM connections
  3. SSM agent is installed on bastion
  4. IAM permissions for SSM sessions

docs.title: Database Not in /etc/hosts
docs.text:
# Run setup to configure hostname forwarding
devo ssm hosts setup

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
Each database automatically gets a unique loopback IP, avoiding conflicts. Check configuration:

devo ssm list

docs.title: Cleanup Port Forwarding (Windows)
docs.text:
# List all port proxy rules
netsh interface portproxy show all

# Delete specific rule
netsh interface portproxy delete v4tov4 listenaddress=127.0.0.2 listenport=5432

# Delete all rules
netsh interface portproxy reset

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
• Loopback IPs (127.0.0.x) are only accessible from your local machine
  • All traffic goes through encrypted SSM tunnels (TLS 1.2+)
  • No SSH keys or direct bastion access required
  • IAM policies control access to SSM sessions
  • /etc/hosts entries are managed in a dedicated section

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use descriptive names: myapp-dev-db instead of db1
  2. Run setup after adding databases: devo ssm hosts setup
  3. Export configuration for team: Share ssm-config.json
  4. Use environment-specific profiles: --profile dev, --profile prod
  5. Install Session Manager Plugin first: Verify before using SSM commands
  6. Clean up on exit: Press Ctrl+C to properly stop connections
  7. Test connections: Verify with devo ssm connect before deploying

docs.text:

docs.text:

  • Description: Required IAM role for CodeArtifact operations
  • Example: 
    devo config set codeartifact.required_role Developer

docs.title: codeartifact.domains
docs.text:
• Type: array of objects
  • Default: []
  • Description: List of CodeArtifact domain configurations
  • Object Structure:
  • domain (string): Domain name
  • repository (string): Repository name
  • namespace (string): NPM namespace

docs.title: Troubleshooting Guide
docs.text: Common issues and solutions for Devo CLI.

docs.title: Command Not Found
docs.text:
Problem: devo: command not found after installation

Solutions:

  1. Restart terminal: 

    # Close and reopen terminal
# Or reload shell configuration
source ~/.bashrc  # or ~/.zshrc

  2. Check PATH: 

    # Verify devo is in PATH
which devo

# Add to PATH if needed
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"

  3. Verify installation: 

    # Check if binary exists
ls -la ~/.local/bin/devo
ls -la /usr/local/bin/devo

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
Problem: Permission denied when running devo

Solutions:

# Make executable
chmod +x ~/.local/bin/devo

# Or reinstall with correct permissions
curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/edu526/devo-cli/main/install.sh | bash

docs.title: Windows Execution Policy Error
docs.text:
Problem: PowerShell blocks script execution

Solution:

# Allow script execution for current user
Set-ExecutionPolicy -Scope CurrentUser RemoteSigned

# Then retry installation
irm https://raw.githubusercontent.com/edu526/devo-cli/main/install.ps1 | iex

docs.title: No Credentials Found
docs.text:
Problem: Unable to locate credentials or NoCredentialsError

Solutions:

  1. Configure AWS CLI: 

    aws configure

  2. Use AWS SSO: 

    aws sso login --profile my-profile
export AWS_PROFILE=my-profile

  3. Verify credentials: 

    aws sts get-caller-identity

docs.title: Access Denied to Bedrock
docs.text:
Problem: AccessDeniedException when using AI features

Solutions:

  1. Enable Bedrock model access:
  2. Go to AWS Console → Bedrock
  3. Navigate to "Model access"

  4. Request access to Claude models

  5. Check IAM permissions: 

    {
  "Effect": "Allow",
  "Action": [
    "bedrock:InvokeModel",
    "bedrock:InvokeModelWithResponseStream"
  ],
  "Resource": "arn:aws:bedrock:*::foundation-model/anthropic.claude-*"
}

  6. Verify region: 

    # Bedrock is not available in all regions
devo config set aws.region us-east-1

docs.title: Wrong AWS Account/Role
docs.text:
Problem: Using wrong AWS account or role

Solutions:

# Check current identity
aws sts get-caller-identity

# Use specific profile
devo --profile production commit

# Set default profile
export AWS_PROFILE=production

docs.title: Configuration Not Loading
docs.text:
Problem: Configuration changes not taking effect

Solutions:

  1. Verify configuration file: 

    devo config path
devo config show

  2. Validate configuration: 

    devo config validate

  3. Reset if corrupted: 

    devo config reset

docs.title: Invalid Configuration Values
docs.text:
Problem: Configuration validation fails

Solutions:

# Check specific value
devo config get aws.region

# Fix invalid value
devo config set aws.region us-east-1

# Or edit manually
devo config edit

docs.title: Commit Command Issues
docs.text:
Problem: No staged changes found

Solution:

# Stage changes first
git add .

# Then generate commit message
devo commit

Problem: Commit message generation fails

Solutions:

  1. Check AWS credentials: 

    aws sts get-caller-identity

  2. Verify Bedrock access: 

    aws bedrock list-foundation-models --region us-east-1

  3. Try different model: 

    devo config set bedrock.model_id us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0

docs.title: Code Reviewer Issues
docs.text:
Problem: Code review fails or returns errors

Solutions:

  1. Check diff size: 

    # Large diffs may timeout
git diff --staged --stat

# Review smaller chunks
git add file1.py
devo code-reviewer

  2. Verify AWS credentials: 

    aws sts get-caller-identity

docs.title: Upgrade Command Issues
docs.text:
Problem: Failed to download latest version

Solutions:

  1. Check internet connection: 

    curl -I https://github.com

  2. Verify GitHub access: 

    curl -I https://api.github.com/repos/edu526/devo-cli/releases/latest

  3. Manual upgrade: 

    # Download manually
curl -L https://github.com/edu526/devo-cli/releases/latest/download/devo-linux-amd64 -o devo
chmod +x devo
sudo mv devo /usr/local/bin/

docs.title: CodeArtifact Login Issues
docs.text:
Problem: Failed to authenticate with CodeArtifact

Solutions:

  1. Check IAM permissions: 

    {
  "Effect": "Allow",
  "Action": [
    "codeartifact:GetAuthorizationToken",
    "codeartifact:GetRepositoryEndpoint",
    "codeartifact:ReadFromRepository",
    "sts:GetServiceBearerToken"
  ],
  "Resource": "*"
}

  2. Verify configuration: 

    devo config get codeartifact.region
devo config get codeartifact.account_id

  3. Use AWS SSO: 

    aws sso login --profile my-profile
devo --profile my-profile codeartifact-login

docs.title: Slow Command Execution
docs.text:
Problem: Commands take long time to execute

Solutions:

  1. Disable version check: 

    export DEVO_SKIP_VERSION_CHECK=1
devo commit

  2. Check network connectivity: 

    ping api.github.com

  3. Use faster Bedrock model: 

    devo config set bedrock.model_id us.anthropic.claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219-v1:0

docs.title: Large Diff Timeouts
docs.text:
Problem: Code review times out on large diffs

Solutions:

# Review smaller chunks
git add specific-files
devo code-reviewer

# Or increase timeout (if supported)
# Split large changes into smaller commits

docs.title: Completion Not Working
docs.text:
Problem: Tab completion doesn't work

Solutions:

  1. Reload shell configuration: 

    source ~/.bashrc  # or ~/.zshrc

  2. Verify completion is loaded: 

    # Zsh
echo $_comps[devo]

# Bash
complete -p devo

  3. Reinstall completion: 

    # Add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc
eval "$(_DEVO_COMPLETE=bash_source devo)"  # Bash
eval "$(_DEVO_COMPLETE=zsh_source devo)"   # Zsh

docs.title: Antivirus False Positive
docs.text:
Problem: Antivirus flags devo binary as malicious

Solutions:

  1. Add exception in antivirus software

  2. Build from source: 

    git clone https://github.com/edu526/devo-cli.git
cd devo-cli
./setup-dev.sh
make build-binary

  3. Use Python installation: 

    pip install -e .

docs.title: Binary Won't Execute
docs.text:
Problem: Binary fails to run

Solutions:

# Check if executable
ls -la $(which devo)

# Make executable
chmod +x $(which devo)

# Check for missing dependencies (Linux)
ldd $(which devo)

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you can't resolve your issue:

  1. Check documentation:
  2. Installation Guide
  3. Configuration Guide

  4. AWS Setup

  5. Enable debug output: 

    # Set verbose logging (if supported)
devo --verbose commit

  6. Report issue:

  7. GitHub Issues
  8. Include:
    • Devo version (devo --version)
    • Operating system
    • Error message
    • Steps to reproduce

docs.text:

Fix: Validate configuration with devo config validate

docs.text:
Cause: Network connectivity issues

Fix: Check internet connection and firewall settings
